Title: Sequence v. UUID as Primary Key — brandur.org
Description: Last month, Cybertec put together an excellent piece on the use of UUIDs vs. bigserial vs IDENTITY as primary keys in a Postgres database. Although freshly written, it’s only the latest talking point in a long-standing discussion amongst DBAs and database nerds that’s been ongoing for years – should you use integers (AKA serials, AKA sequences) or UUIDs as primary keys?

Title: Email vs Capitalism: A Story About Why We Can't Have Nice Things : dylanbeattie.net
Mastering Concurrency in Rust: Advanced Patterns with Async/Await and Tokio
Description: Concurrency in modern software development is not just a luxury but a necessity. As applications grow more complex and user expectations for responsiveness increase, developers need to harness the power of concurrent programming to build efficient and scalable systems. Rust, with its unique ownership model, safety guarantees, and powerful concurrency primitives, provides an excellent foundation for tackling these challenges. In this post, we’ll dive deep into concurrency in Rust, focusing on advanced patterns with async/await and the Tokio runtime.

Title: Four Years of Traveling the World: Lessons I Learned as a Digital Nomad
Description: The life of a digital nomad is far from the idealised image of working on a paradise beach in Bali. Is not for everyone. Would you dare to try it?

Title: The Future of Data Management: An Enabler of AI Development? A Basic Illustration with RAG, Open Standards, and Data Contracts
Description:
Context In a recent meetup I organized in my hometown of Lille, I had the pleasure of hosting Jean-Georges Perrin, who provided a comprehensive introduction to data contracts. As a geek, I felt compelled to test this concept to fully grasp its practical implications.
The goal of this article is to demonstrate how data contracts can be applied to and add value within a small ecosystem facing cross-domain challenges.
To illustrate, I will use my personal experience in the fields I work in, which can be categorized into two separate domains:

Title: One year of solo dev, wrapping up the grant-funded work
Description:
A year ago I walked out of the office for the last time. I handed in my corpo laptop, said some good-byes, and since then I have been my own boss.
This first year has been funded by an NLnet grant, which I’m in the midst of wrapping up. As of now, the work is all done, the final request for payment has been sent.
There’s a similar last-day-of-school levity to both these events.

Title: Jared Norman | Software Consultant, Open-Source Maintainer, and Solidus Expert
Description: I'm Jared Norman, a software consultant, open-source maintainer, and member of the Solidus core team. I believe that the software industry is short-sighted and fails to capitalize on its own best ideas. My company, Super Good Software, helps organizations learn from the past and build software more effectively.
